title: 107_s1414
content: The "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" is also known as the "State Incentives for Teacher Testing and Merit Pay Act." It amends Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to provide incentives for teacher testing and merit pay at the state level. The Secretary will award funds to states that test teachers every 3-5 years, have a merit-based compensation system, and require continuing education credits for recertification. Funding is 50% of the excess appropriation over 2001, capped at $600,000,000. The amount appropriated for awards under this section exceeds $600,000,000 or each State is eligible to receive an award. States will receive an award based on the total amount available and the number of eligible States. Funds can be used for activities described in section 2207. The definition of 'State' includes all 50 States and the District of Columbia. The effective date for the amendments is October 1, 2001. SEC. 3 allows States to use Federal education funds for teacher testing or merit pay programs. SEC. 4 introduces a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary school expenses in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A nonrefundable credit is allowed against the tax for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses paid by an individual, limited to $1000 per qualifying student with a maximum of $500 for tuition expenses. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent or relative enrolled in school on a full-time basis. The text discusses a nonrefundable tax credit for qualified education expenses, limited to $1000 per student. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent or relative enrolled in school full-time. The section also mentions that no double benefit is allowed, and taxpayers can elect to not apply for the credit in a taxable year. The text introduces a new tax credit for contributions to elementary and secondary schools, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. A new tax credit allows for a 75% credit on qualified charitable contributions for the taxable year, with a maximum credit of $500 for individuals ($1,000 for joint returns) and $100,000 for corporations. Qualified charitable contribution refers to cash contributions to a school tuition organization. A school tuition organization is defined as an organization that allocates at least 90% of its income to scholarships for elementary and secondary school students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunch. These scholarships are for education expenses up to 12th grade and are excluded from gross income. The text discusses rules and limitations regarding tax deductions for contributions to school tuition organizations providing scholarships for students up to 12th grade. It includes provisions on not allowing double benefits, limitations on the credit amount based on tax calculations, treatment of controlled groups as one taxpayer, and the option for taxpayers to elect not to apply the credit for a taxable year. The text discusses rules and limitations for tax deductions on contributions to school tuition organizations providing scholarships. It includes provisions on not allowing double benefits, limitations on credit amount based on tax calculations, treatment of controlled groups as one taxpayer, and the option for taxpayers to elect not to apply the credit for a taxable year. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The text introduces a new credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. A new tax credit is introduced for eligible educators, allowing a maximum credit of $1,000 for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses. Eligible educators include teachers, counselors, and aides who work at least 900 hours in a school year. Qualified expenses include books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. The new tax credit for eligible educators allows a maximum credit of $1,000 for qualified education expenses, including books, supplies, computer equipment, and materials used in the classroom. No double benefit is allowed, and the credit cannot exceed the regular tax for the year minus other credits. Taxpayers can elect to not apply for the credit in a taxable year. Section 30C provides a tax credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who provide classroom materials. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Additionally, Section 7 adjusts the gross income by considering professional development expenses of these teachers. The amendment allows eligible educators to deduct up to $1,500 for professional development expenses related to their teaching subjects. The program must be approved by the local educational agency. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to allow a deduction for professional development expenses for eligible educators. The deduction is limited to expenses exceeding certain amounts for the taxable year, with the amendments applying to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
